Award.AwardTitle: Entropy-Consistent Moment-Closure Approximations of Kinetic Boltzmann Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is concerned with the development of mathematical models and corresponding state-of-the-art computational methods for simulating and predicting the dynamics of complex fluid systems, such as those arising from multiphase flows and plasma. The ability to predict the dynamics of these complex fluid systems is of vital importance in understanding a wide range of phenomena such as particulate flow in the atmosphere, fuel sprays in combustion engines, magnetically-confined fusion reactors, laser-plasma accelerators, space weather, and astrophysical events. The underlying physics of such systems are often well-represented by kinetic models that represent the state of the fluid in terms of probability density functions. The main challenge in accurately simulating these kinetic models is that solutions live in a high-dimensional phase space and contain information over wide-ranging spatial and temporal scales. The goal of this research is to develop reduced models that simultaneously capture the important physics and can be more readily solved on modern computer architectures. As part of this research effort, graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in mathematical modeling and computational mathematics. Students from groups that are underrepresented in applied and computational mathematics will be encouraged to participate in the research efforts.

The primary objective of this research is to develop accurate and efficient computational methods for solving kinetic models of both polydisperse multiphase flows and plasma flows via entropy-consistent moment closures. The purpose of moment-closure techniques is to reduce high-dimensional kinetic models to more computationally tractable approximations. However, determining a suitable moment closure is a mathematical challenge; a general approach that combines desirable mathematical features remains elusive. This research will pursue two related approaches: (1) using quasi-exponential representations of the underlying kinetic distribution functions, and (2) using delta functions in conjunction with entropy maximization. Novel moment-inversion algorithms and high-order numerical schemes will be developed. The resulting codes will be implemented on massively parallel computers. These techniques will be applied to problems in polydisperse multiphase flows and plasma flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A gas is a collection of molecules moving through space that interact with each other through external forces and collisions between the molecules. Rarefied gas dynamics (RGD) is the study of gases in a regime where the mean-free path of molecular collisions (the average distance a molecule will go before undergoing a collision) is comparable to the characteristic length scale of the system (e.g., the size of the device or aircraft). RGD is an important regime for microfluidic devices, where the characteristic length scale will generally be small, and for high-altitude aircraft and spacecraft, where the mean-free will generally be large due to the relatively low gas densities.

A plasma is a collection of positively and negatively charged ions that behave similarly to gases but are now subject to electromagnetic interactions. Like gases, plasma can be in various collisional regimes, including many situations where direct particle collisions are relatively weak compared to other effects (i.e., rarefied regimes). Examples of plasma applications include magnetically confined fusion reactors, laser-plasma accelerators, space weather, and astrophysical flows.

Kinetic models are widely used to simulate the dynamics of plasmas and rarefied gases; they arise from a statistical mechanics approximation of the underlying particle motion and typically manifest as nonlinear integral-differential equations defined in high-dimensional phase space. The challenge of reducing this phase space to a lower dimensional space is called the moment-closure problem. The goal is to replace the full kinetic distribution function with a (hopefully small) set of moments (e.g., mass, momentum, and energy); unfortunately, with only a finite set of moments, the underlying evolution equations are not closed, and additional assumptions must be made.

The goals of this research project are: (1) to develop new moment-closure techniques that allow kinetic models to be accurately modeled by lower-dimensional fluid models; (2) to develop numerical methods that can approximate the solutions to the resulting fluid models; and (3) implement the resulting numerical methods in computer code that is computationally efficient.

The key results from this research include all the following.

(1)     A class of techniques known as quadrature-based moment closures (QMOM) were mathematically studied and high-order numerical methods were developed to accurately approximate solutions to the resulting fluid equations. Critically, to obtain high-order accurate solutions, new computational strategies were developed that prevent the approximate solution from producing unphysical solutions (e.g., solutions with negative densities and pressures).

(2)     A novel class of moment-closure techniques, known as spectral element closure (SEC), was developed as an alternative to existing closures in the literature. In standard moment closures, global moments are introduced to replace the full kinetic distribution function. In SEC, the idea is first to divide phase space into smaller pieces and then introduce moments that are local to these smaller pieces. The idea was successfully tested on the Vlasov-Poisson system from plasma physics.

(3)     In the special case of linear kinetic equations – these arise naturally in the modeling of neutron transport, which is important in the design of nuclear reactors – a novel solution approach was developed using the Radon transform (an integral transform widely used in medical imagining applications) coupled to high-order Chebyshev spectral methods. The resulting approach is agnostic to the precise moment-closure approximation, and it was tested on a standard approach for linear kinetic equations known as the spherical harmonics (PN) moment-closure.

(4)     A novel class of numerical methods was developed that allows for more efficient calculation of solutions to both kinetic and fluid models. This approach is known as the hierarchical regionally implicit discontinuous Galerkin (HRIDG) method. This approach was successfully tested on the Vlasov-Poisson system from plasma physics.

(5)     A novel class of numerical methods was developed for solving the Cahn-Hilliard Navier-Stokes model of multiphase flows. Such models arise in many applications, including chemical/biological reactors, bio-microfluidics, and manufacturing. A key aspect of this research was the development of energy-stable numerical methods. This work involved numerical method development, in-depth theoretical analysis of the resulting schemes, implementation of these methods into software, and the utilization of high-performance computing techniques, including parallelization and adaptive mesh-refinement.

The research efforts involved the training of several PhD students. The work resulted in computer codes that have been made publicly available. One of the purposes of this is to allow the research findings to be disseminated more directly than through journal publications. These codes are freely available online through a BSD 2-Clause License from the Open Source Initiative.
